@SageSaga Dang, this is taking me back to /my/ childhood where all I had was PBS, static and VHS Tapes.
ABC, NBC, and CBS was all we had for most of my childhood
we got better rabbit ears for the upstairs TV and could get UPN and FOX as well as - something else-
watched Ronin Warriors on that- and also DBZ and Sailor Moon

I remember (shortly before getting DirectTV) we /somehow/ found a way to get Fox Kids, but it was very fuzzy and some times someone had to stand in a weird way near the TV to make it a little less fuzzy.
eventually we got SATELLITE - not direct TV
like one of those giant black satellite dishes?
a 5 foot radius Dish on a 6 foot tall bar
I remember the few houses that had those in my town years ago.
Wasn't that awesome! All those /new/ channels and no static!
a giant tree blocked half of the satellites we should have been able to get
but we got the Sci-Fi channel!

Make sure they supply you with a flamethrower for bathroom duty.
9.50 isnt enough to just sit in the store
Does your place have a Dunkin Donuts or coffeshop inside?
We do have a coffee bar, and the store is relatively nice
It's just small compared to places like Sheetz that are within 5 minutes driving distance
And seriously, we need more employees!
When your part time and full time staff basically work the same hours (and in case of part-time even more), your hiring situation is SNAFU
Yeah usually high availability businesses have a bigger pool of employees to keep things flexible.
I'm just waiting for the modern economy to burst because corporations focus so heavily on the numbers that all other sectors of the business suffer :/
Numbers, numbers...what's it matter in the end?
Yeah the focus too much nowadays is: CHEAP! CHEAP! CHEAP!
And our biggest issue right now is that they want the gas station to be 24/7, but they only allow a single person to work at night
Cheap is never good, and often just a hassle.
There's no extra pay to incentivize that shift, AND it's the only time our store has been robbed
So: Shit hours, no extra pay, increased chance of being held at gun / knifepoint.  What incentive is there for somebody to take that shift?
When you shop for something as a consumer the cheapest option is always garbage.
I wish business decision makers would understand that.
Their heads are so far up their own asses with their precious "numbers"
Like Mr Krabs... only understand less cost.
I will laugh if a huge section of retail just up and quit
Get tired of the bullshit management / algorithmic worship
When they equate "good job" to being "done cheap", often they sacrifice the quality of the end product.
See what happens when people won't put up with your treatment
Is there no way to fix it?
It's going to get worse before it gets better
Corporations are increasingly using algorithms and data analysis to "optimize" business
Meaning, working as few hours as possible, having as few people as needed
What happens is, the good people making the right decision to keep things afloat get pushed out or leave
Clothing store used to have 10 employees at any given time
But then their numbers started dipping because the store was being used for online returns
When you think about it though, it won't work in the long run.
But corporate didn't count online sales in the area towards that store's numbers, only the returns
ANd the companies would have to change for the better....
So they saw, "Oh shit, people are returning a lot of stuff to this store!"  So they considered it underperforming, and cut the number of employees back to 4
Well, the idiots left lose sight of what the business was originally intended to do.
Well now customers complain that there's noone to ring up their purchases, because now they only have 4 people to stock, run, and check people out
Smaller more effective companies steal their market
There's a reason we had the "retail apocalypse" a few years ago
And how it's probably going to keep going strong
Fun fact, about 16M people work in retail
Overworked, underpaid, abused to the fullest with unpredictable scheduling
I do not cry for those who lose their jobs when a company or industry dies
Let the rot and corruption fade, and something new and better take its place
Retail has only survived for so long because the jobs are low skill and easy to pick up
This economy needs a good ol' fashioned mutiny.
The more I hear, the more scared I am for my entry into the world.
If enough people say "fuck this" and learn really good skills to find employment elsewhere, the old retail model will finally either have to change or die
I'm trying to cut back on my hours at work so I can do other stuff
The rise of small businesses lately poses the biggest threat to overgrown conglomerates.
I have a degree, but am not using it
If they steal enough market share, the big co's will begin hurting.
I'm hoping, if I put the work in, to make my life as a surveyor..
While I still want to pursue art related interests, I realize that I would rather shake off the rust and get a programming job than work at a gas station / retail
But I want to be able to draw too.
I think what I really want is to work no more than 4 days a week at my current job
The level of multitasking is just exhausting
One thing that disturbs me greatly lately seems to be the lack of managers understanding what their employees fully do.
I think as that trend increases things get increasingly dangerous.
If you're self motivated and not lazy and have good instincts it is good. More hands-off.
Weeellll...I definitely need work on being 'not lazy'.

...but it opens the door for more plausible deniability systemically and can create problems where a decision is made that no one person makes, and suddenly the ship is alarmingly off course toward dangerous waters.
Weeeell. I do have a 'head in the sand' proble
I've never really got out of the habit of hoping a problem just goes away if I don't pay attention to it.
I like my manager, it's just annoying because corporate is cracking down on a lot of things

here's my scheduled hours since I've been hired
Yeah, we have a corporate, but were a small subsidiary, and the vibes coming from them are scary.
31 - 28 - 35 - 35 - 35 - 35 (weeks 4 and 5 I didn't work those hours due to illness)
I'm giving it 2 more weeks, and if I don't get less hours, I'm asking my manager to cut my hours back.  Easiest way?  Just cut a day off.
Might drop me below 30 hours a week, but I still consider that preferable :/
Ofc, I need to review our policy on health insurance to see if I'd be eligible at all if I drop below that magic 30 number
But seriously, I should not be working more hours than some full time employees!!!

I made too many mistakes last year.
